fact: The term 'ḥūr' refers to intensely white-skinned women with wide beautiful eyes, created specially for Paradise.
They are described as 'like well-protected pearls', signifying purity and untouchability.
'ʿĪn' means wide beautiful eyes, symbolizing attractiveness and perfection of gaze.
They are created in a special creation not from the daughters of Adam.
They are created perfectly in form and symmetry.
They are described as virgins (ʿuruban atrāban) who are loving and of equal age.
They never menstruate, urinate, defecate or suffer any impurity.
They never grow old or lose beauty.
Their eyes are described as intensely white and deeply black, a striking contrast.
They are secluded and untouched by any man or jinn before their husbands.
They are like rubies and coral in beauty and luster.
They are described as chaste, restraining their glances to their husbands only.
Their love and passion for their husbands is pure and unwavering.
They are of equal age as their husbands in Paradise.
They are created anew, indicating perfect new bodies without flaw.
Their companionship is considered one of the great rewards for the believers.
They are adorned with bracelets of gold and garments of silk.
They sing for their husbands with the most beautiful voices.
Each believer will be given two wives from the hūr al-ʿīn at minimum.
The marrow of their shin bones will be visible through their flesh due to their clarity and brightness.
They will not experience jealousy or hatred among themselves.
They are described as intensely beautiful beyond imagination.
They are created to please and delight their husbands.
They are considered a reward for the patience and good deeds of believers.
They are free from worldly defects such as fatigue or illness.
They never become pregnant or give birth.
source: Sahih Muslim 2834; Tafsir Ibn Kathir on 56:36

fact: They are described as intensely white with a hint of rosy color (fair-skinned with blush).
They have large dark eyes with intense contrast (ḥūr ʿīn).
They are modest and reserved in their gaze, looking only at their husbands.
They are described as 'chaste' (qasirāt al-ṭarf), who do not look at anyone except their husbands.
Their voices are melodious and sweet, enchanting their husbands.
They will sing for their husbands in Paradise in a voice no creation has ever heard.
They wear garments of silk and fine brocade.
They are described as reclining on green cushions and rich carpets with their husbands.
Their jewelry is made of gold and pearls.
They are described as being of the same age as their husbands.
Their love is intense (ʿuruban means loving, passionate, affectionate).
They do not envy or compete with each other for their husbands' affection.
They are free from jealousy or malice towards co-wives.
They are created directly by Allah and not born from human parents.
They are exclusively for the believing men of Paradise as a reward.
They are housed in pavilions made of hollowed pearls.
Each pavilion is sixty miles wide.
In each pavilion are multiple wives, each unseen by the others.
They are described as residing with their husbands in private tents made of pearls.
They are described as 'qasirāt al-ṭarf' — women who restrain their gaze exclusively for their husbands.
Their gaze does not wander; they have complete devotion to their husbands.
They are secluded in pavilions, not exposed to other men.
No human or jinn has ever touched them before their husbands.
They are created anew and not born from earthly parents.
They are intensely loving and affectionate (ʿurub), passionately devoted to their spouses.
They are clothed in fine green silk and brocade garments.
They are surrounded by fragrance and musk that fills Paradise.
Their voices are melodious and sweet, pleasing to their husbands.
They sing for their husbands in praise and affection.
Each man in Paradise will be given multiple hūr as part of his reward.
The least reward for a man in Paradise is seventy-two hūr plus his worldly wife if she was righteous.
If his worldly wife enters Paradise, she becomes more beautiful than the hūr.
They have radiant faces shining like luminous stars.
Each believing man in Paradise will be granted multiple hūr as part of his reward.
The least in rank among the people of Paradise will have two wives from the hūr.
The martyr (shahīd) will be granted seventy-two hūr as part of his reward.
The believer's worldly wife, if righteous, will be superior in beauty to the hūr and will be his chief wife.
They are free from jealousy, envy, or rivalry among themselves.
They will be fully content and pleased with their husbands forever.
source: Qur'an 98:8; Tafsir Ibn Kathir (applied to spouses of Jannah)

fact: They are described as having clear, radiant skin shining like light.
Their sweat is fragrant like musk and does not have unpleasant odor.
They are free from bodily hair except where it enhances beauty.
source: Tafsir Ibn Kathir (paradise bodies are perfected)

fact: Their bodies are translucent such that the marrow of their bones can be seen through their flesh.
They are described as tall and elegant in stature.
They are created from saffron (or a similar heavenly substance) according to classical tafsīr.
They do not become tired or fatigued from intimacy or service.
They will always appear eager and joyful to meet their husbands.
They emit light that brightens the palaces of Paradise.
They have a radiant glow surpassing the brilliance of the sun.
They will never experience sadness, sorrow, or distress.
They speak gently and kindly, never harsh or argumentative.
They will praise and glorify Allah along with their husbands in Paradise.
They are adorned with jewelry made of gold, silver, and pearls.
They wear garments of fine silk, brocade, and green fabrics.
They dwell in magnificent pavilions made of hollowed pearls.
Each pavilion is sixty miles high and wide.
They are free from fatigue and exhaustion; their energy never diminishes.
They are granted perfect manners and character.
They remain forever youthful around the age of thirty-three.
They have no bodily impurities — no urine, stool, saliva, or menstruation.
Their breath smells sweeter than musk.
They laugh and smile with joy when meeting their husband.
They do not age or lose beauty over eternity.
Their hair is described as long, beautiful, and black like the wing of a crow.
source: Ibn Abi Hatim in Tafsir; classed hasan by Albani

fact: Their voices are melodious and pleasing to hear.
They greet their husbands with peace and words of welcome.
They are not jealous of co-wives and live in harmony.
They have been prepared specifically for the believers they are paired with.
They are described as resembling the most beautiful women of the world but far surpass them in beauty.
Their bodies are perfectly proportioned — no physical defect.
They are perpetually in a state of happiness and contentment.
They never experience sickness or disease.
They are clothed with garments so fine that their beauty beneath can be seen.
Each believer has the strength for intimacy equal to that of 100 men.
They are affectionate and loving ('urub) — always inclined towards their husband.
They are described as 'restraining their gaze' — they do not look at other men.
Their loyalty is perfect — they remain devoted eternally.
They are constantly renewed in youth and beauty.
Their companionship removes all loneliness from Paradise dwellers.
They are granted in direct response to the believer's patience and piety in this life.
They are seated on couches next to their husbands.
They share meals and drink with their husbands in blissful gatherings.
Their companionship is described as everlasting, with no divorce or separation.
They are created without toil or suffering — pure gifts of Allah.
Their dwellings are private and peaceful, away from disturbance.
Their companionship increases the believer's joy in Paradise.
They never display anger or annoyance towards their husbands.
They are free from all negative emotions like pride or arrogance.
Their touch brings comfort and bliss, not fatigue.
They have sweet and playful speech, adding to the pleasure of Paradise.
They never bear children — there is no pregnancy or childbirth in Paradise.
Their bodies are perfectly clean, never needing washing.
They are described as reclining with their husbands in total relaxation.
They bring an eternal sense of fulfillment and companionship.
Their beauty is renewed each time they meet their husbands.
They are a manifestation of Allah's mercy and generosity to the believers.
Their smiles and joy increase the bliss of Paradise's atmosphere.
They never feel hunger or thirst — their joy is uninterrupted.
They are immune from boredom — no moment feels repetitive.
They are among the adornments of Paradise, part of its beauty.
They do not sleep — bliss is constant, wakefulness is perfect.
They have a unique fragrance that fills their dwelling.
Their companionship never leads to disputes — no conflict exists in Paradise.
They sing praises to their husbands and remind them of Allah's favors.
They express gratitude for their husband's piety that led them to Paradise.
They share the rewards of Paradise feasts and drinks.
They are perfectly gentle and have no harshness.
They delight in the remembrance of Allah with their husbands.
Their beauty never diminishes, even after eternal companionship.
Their companionship is considered part of the greatest reward after seeing Allah.
They will never wish for anything beyond what they are given.
They will rejoice at every elevation of their husband's rank in Paradise.
They inspire tranquility — no anxiety remains when they are with their husbands.
They are fully satisfied emotionally and spiritually — not just physically.
Their loyalty and love increase the more their husbands thank Allah.
Their companionship is free from jealousy between worldly wives and hūr.
They are living signs of Allah's creative power and mercy.
Their joy intensifies during gatherings with the people of Paradise.
Their existence is eternal — they never die.
Their homes are designed uniquely for each believer.
They never commit sin or displeasing actions.
They are created to bring happiness without any test or trial.
Their joy is magnified when the believer is elevated to see Allah.
They are companions who never betray trust.
They embody eternal love — not just beauty.
They will remind their husbands of Allah's mercy and forgiveness.
Their very presence is counted as a reward and a form of delight (na'īm).
They have no need for sustenance, yet share in Paradise food and drink as joy.
Their companionship is one of the signs of ultimate success (fawz al-'azīm).
